title: On Asynchronous Communication
subtitle: A Note on Productivity
intro: A brief reflection on the importance of asynchronous communication in creative and technical work environments.
content: The constant pressure for immediate response is a significant drain on deep, focused work. Adopting an 'async-first' mindset is crucial. It's not about ignoring people; it's about respecting everyone's time and focus. By defaulting to email, documents, and project management tools over instant messages and meetings, we create space for thoughtful replies and uninterrupted progress. This memo serves as a reminder to prioritize deep work and build systems that support it.

title: The Unseen Value of Side Projects
subtitle: Beyond the Portfolio Piece
intro: Side projects are more than just resume boosters; they are playgrounds for innovation and learning.
content: While the primary goal of a side project might seem to be creating a polished piece for a portfolio, its true value often lies in the process. It's a low-stakes environment to experiment with new technologies, tackle unfamiliar problems, and make mistakes without professional consequences. These explorations are where true learning and innovation happen, often feeding back into one's primary work in unexpected and valuable ways. This memo is an encouragement to start that 'silly' idea—it might be more valuable than you think.

title: The Future You Will Thank You
subtitle: A Note on Documentation
intro: A short memo on the importance of documenting your work, even when it feels like a chore.
content: Writing documentation can feel like a thankless task at the moment, an extra step when you'd rather move on to the next problem. But good documentation is a gift to your future self and your colleagues. It's the difference between a project that can be understood and maintained, and one that becomes a black box of 'here be dragons'. Whether it's code comments, a README file, or a full wiki, taking the time to explain the 'why' behind your decisions is one of the highest-leverage activities you can do.

title: Embrace Boredom
subtitle: A Note on Creativity
intro: In a world of constant stimulation, boredom has become a rare and valuable commodity.
content: Our brains are not designed for the firehose of information we subject them to daily. Creativity and deep thought don't happen when we're scrolling through feeds or jumping between tasks. They happen in the quiet moments, the 'in-between' times when our minds are free to wander. This memo is a small encouragement to intentionally create moments of boredom in your day. Go for a walk without a podcast. Stare out the window. Let your mind be fallow. It's in these moments that the best ideas often take root.

title: The Power of Defaults
subtitle: A Note on System Design
intro: The default settings in any system—be it software, a team process, or a personal habit—are incredibly powerful.
content: Most people will stick with the default option most of the time. This is known as default bias. As designers and builders, we can leverage this for good. Does your system default to being secure? Does your process default to open communication? Does your UI default to an accessible font size? Making the 'right' choice the 'easy' choice is one of the most effective ways to influence behavior at scale. This memo is a reminder to think critically about the defaults we set, as they will shape the landscape more than any other single choice.
